trial_identification.studytitle: dexamethasone and tramadol as additives to local anesthetics in ultrasound guided supraclavicular brachial plexus (SCBP) block and duration of analgesia.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effect of tramadol or dexamethasone added to lidocaine for a ultrasound guided supraclavicular brachial plexus (SCBP) block on the onset, duration of sensory and motor blockade and first request of analgesia.

conditions.healthcondition: analgesia after ultrasound guided nerve block

interventions.interventions: 15 ml lidocaine 2% + 8 mg dexamethasone in single shot ultrasound guided supraclavicular brachial plexus block.
interventions.comparator:
comparator group: 15 ml of lidocaine 2% + 2 ml tramadol (50 mg/ml = 100 mg) in single shot ultrasound guided supraclavicular brachial plexus block
control group: 15 ml of lidocaine 2% + 2 ml saline in single shot ultrasound guided supraclavicular brachial plexus block

primaryOutcome.outcome: Duration of postoperative analgesia:time interval between performing nerve block and the first analgesia request
and proportion of patients requiring analgesic supplementation for the first 24h

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Duration of sensory block was defined as the time between local anesthetic (LA) administration and the complete offset of sensory anesthesia on each nerve by pinprick test.
Duration of motor block was defined as the time from LA injection to score 5 of Bromage modified scale of each nerve.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: patients undergoing upper limb wrist/hand/elbow or distal arm surgery
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: history of lung disease, obesity (body mass index > 30 kg/m2), a history of chronic pain or psychiatric disorder, drug or alcohol abuse, and hypersensitivity to local anesthetics

trial_design.concealment: Allocation was concealed by sealed opaque envelopes

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
During nerve blocks (which can control postoperative pain effectively), various drugs have been proposed in combination with local anesthetics (LA) to help reduce onset time and to prolong the duration of action and postoperative analgesia. Clonidine, epinephrine, and opioids are such examples but they are not without side effects.
Tramadol and dexamethasone was proposed as safe adjuvents to LA but there were no study comparing those two molecules in ultrasound guided (US) peripheral nerve blocks.
